subject: Calculate MTU on every network fetch instead of on create
commit_message:
Calculate MTU on every network fetch instead of on create

Today, existing networks may not reflect MTU configured for
neutron-server, if they were created when neutron-server was using
different MTU setup for its infrastructure, or when it was using bad
default values for network MTUs (specifically, before Mitaka, all networks
were getting MTU = 0 by default, disabling both advertisement and data
path MTU size enforcement).

This patch stops persisting MTU in the database on network create and
instead calculate it on every network resource fetch.

DocImpact Now changes to MTU configuration options immediately affect
          existing network MTUs, not just new networks.

UpgradeImpact Existing networks with invalid MTU persisted in database
              may change their MTU values to reflect configuration.

Change-Id: Iee4f5037bf10b73ba98464143b183aacb59c22f2

subject: Standardise tempest role
commit_message:
Standardise tempest role

All of our roles have a standard pattern for installing services,
however tempest does things slightly differently.  I think most of this
is legacy and this commit brings tempest in line (for the most part)
with how other roles are written.

Note that tempest now has a ``tempest`` cli, and in a future commit we
will update this role to use that instead.  This will allow us to skip
the additional step of cloning the tempest git repo to act as a working
directory when running tests.

For some background as to why this work is being done, newer versions
of tempest are failing when run in an IRR because we are not installing
urllib3 into tempest's venv.  This is not an issue when we do an
integrated build because the repo server actually installs tempest into
the tempest venv, and all requirements get satisfied.  However, when we
install tempest without a repo server we simply install
tempest_pip_packages (which previously did not include tempest itself)
into the tempest venv.  We could update update tempest_pip_packages to
include urllib3, but doing so creates duplicate work as this
requirement is already captured in tempest's requirements.txt.

Conflicts:
	defaults/main.yml
	tasks/tempest_install.yml
	tests/test-vars.yml

Change-Id: I6f3c36a8150b83afabae8d397d5fc7340dbc93fd
(cherry picked from commit 75bd092b9e66e4ef79bfc4449ec60901496128d4)

subject: Thread-safety review
commit_message:
Thread-safety review

Manually reviewed source code to identify:
- blocking functions [Note(thread-safety): blocking function]
- blocking calls [Note(thread-safety): blocking call]
- potential thread safety issues [FIXME(thread-safety)]

In summary, there are only two main kinds thread safety issues
identified:
1. Every time the API model converts a UUID to a name via the DB,
   but because the call is a blocking call, the executing greenthread
   may yield control. But the time the greenthread resumes, the name
   obtained from the DB may not refer to the item identified by the
   original UUID any more.
   If the original request was done by name (converted to UUID for
   API), then the behavior might be acceptable. If user says
   "delete nova", but by the time the request is processed nove
   refers to something else, tough luck. But the behavior is not
   acceptable, however, if the original user request was by UUID.
2. Similar to the issue of the synchronizer interrupting a,
   datasource creation, there is an analogous issue with
   datasource deletion.

Reviewed files:
- congress/api/*
- congress/dse2/*
- congress/policy_engine/agnostic.py
- congress/datasources/datasource_driver.py
- congress/datasources/datasource_utils.py
- congress/managers/datasource.py
- congress/utils.py

Note: I do not expect this analysis to be complete.

Add __ne__ built-in function

In Python 3 __ne__ by default delegates to __eq__ and inverts the
result, but in Python 2 they urge you to define __ne__ when you
define __eq__ for it to work properly [1].There are no implied
relationships among the comparison operators. The truth of x==y
does not imply that x!=y is false. Accordingly, when defining
__eq__(), one should also define __ne__() so that the operators
will behave as expected.
[1]https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__ne__

subject: Replace _transpose_component with _filter_component
commit_message:
Replace _transpose_component with _filter_component

The _transpose_component method needs to be adjusted as it currently
causes attribute lookups on Resource instances to differ
depending on how they were constructed. This is an oversight from the
refactoring of this class, as data is stored internally using
server-side names instead of client-side names, but the
_transpose_component method was implemented when data was being stored
in client-side naming, i.e., how the Body and Header attributes are
named on Resource classes.

This oversight happened for two reasons:

1. The Resource.list call doesn't use _transpose_component but other
calls, e.g., Resource.get, do. At least for me, I find it easier during
sanity checks against a live OpenStack cloud to use the list methods,
look at instances in the list, and check certain attributes match what I
set them to. We don't have a strong functional test suite, but that's
where this would have been caught, as we'd be able to call list and then
get each of the items individually and ensure they have the same
values. Such a test would have failed as a number of attributes would
expect values and return None when retrieved via `get` calls.

2. The manual testing I had been doing in lieu of #1 was not
sufficiently thorough, as it was generally looking at only a few
attributes, and those attributes didn't require the _transpose_component
code path. When an attribute's client-side name matches the server-side
name, everything works fine regardless of how the underlying data was
obtained. So checking Server.status will always work, but
Server.created_at depends on how you got your response.

Given the following two calls:

a = list(conn.compute.servers())[0]
b = conn.compute.get_server(a.id)

`a.created_at` would work as expected, because Resource.list doesn't
call _transpose_component. The `created_at` attribute looks for a key
"created" that came from the server-side response data. Because
Resource.list wasn't transposing the data, it was stored appropriately
as "created" and the body manager knew to look in the dictionary for
"created" when a user access `a.created_at`.

However, `b.created_at` would not work as expected and would return
None. This is because Resource.get was sending the response body through
_transpose_component, which caused the "created" key to be stored
internally as "created_at". The body manager would then look for
"created" in the dictionary when looking at the mapping of client to
server names, and it wouldn't find anything beacuse we went against the
mapping and stored as a client name. It would thusly return the default
setting for that Body instance, which is None.

An easy fix is to just remove _transpose_component and all of its
uses in the Resource class as well as one subclass. Several tests
were mocking it out so they were also updated to remove the reference.

However, as just removing allows extraneous keys into our internal
dictionaries, switching _transpose_component to more of a filter model
is a better solution. This way we only return a dictionary including
keys that we're expecting to actually work with, rather than letting
everything possible in, which a simple removal would do. One example of
a place where this approach to the fix matters is in the Keypair
resource, where we are ignoring the "id" key that is both
inconsistently available and contains inconsistent values. That
resource looks to the "name" key as both the name attribute and an
alternate id, which this change supports properly. Just removing
_transpose_component reintroduces the inconsistent `id` internally,
which then makes it possible to access it via the `id` attribute on
Keypair, which breaks the id/name separation and consistency.

Change-Id: Ida7c68c78910ee7adc9d9b73ca9cf280bc303cf5
Closes-Bug: 1600365

subject: Spread instances across NUMA nodes
commit_message:
Spread instances across NUMA nodes

NUMA placement criteria is undefined and produces unexpected behavior.

This patch fixes how instances are placed over NUMA nodes. The current
behavior has undesired effects, as packing all instances to node 0: e.g:
when hw:numa_nodes=1, the result was to pack all instances on node 0,
leaving the other nodes free (unused):
instance1 --> node0, instance2 --> node0, instance3 --> node0

The new criteria optimizes NUMA usage by spreading instances across all
NUMA nodes, by choosing/favoring the less packed ones:
instance1 --> node0, instance2 --> node1, instance3 --> node2

Some other possible criteria are: packing or random. A new config setting
in the flavor or image metadata is required to implement those, though.
Also, for packing, there are some (non-trivial) changes required to make
the cell node accountable, by updating host_cell.avail_cpus.

use keystoneauth and OpenStack clients

The parser should not rely on the OS_* environment variables for
authentication, as it will fail with more complex setups, when using the
"clouds.yaml" configuration file or when being called through osc with
arguments instead of environment variables.

Moreover, the client should not use "requests" directly to do GETs to
access the nova flavors and glance images, but it should use the
existing clients.

When used through the python-openstackclient it is possible to force the
client to request authentication. The authentication will be handled by
the client, so that the parser does not need to worry about it (so that
authentication plugins can be used). Then, the existing authentication
session can be reused for all the client interaction with OpenStack to
fetch the flavor and images information.

subject: Remove two races during the L->M Keystone under httpd migration
commit_message:
Remove two races during the L->M Keystone under httpd migration

After adding the upgrade step to migrate keystone under httpd, we
left two small races in process:
1) The first race could result in the following error:
Graceful restart requested, doing restart (98)Address already in use: AH00072: make_sock: could not bind to address 192.0.2.14:35357

This is likely caused by removing the keystone resource and
changing constraints in a single pacemaker CIB transaction.
We are not guaranteed that pacemaker will first remove keystone
and then attempt to restart httpd due to the changed constraints.
To address this we unmanage the httpd resource before the constraint
changes and we remanage it later.

2) The second race is because after the cib-push we were not
guaranteed that the later upgrade step that reloads the httpd
configuration via 'systemctl reload httpd' was run after
httpd was started everywhere and we could get the following error:
07 07:51:14 overcloud-controller-0 systemd[1]: Unit httpd.service cannot be reloaded because it is inactive.

We add a check_resource httpd started after we remanage the httpd
resource, in order to guarantee that the httpd resource is up and
running at this point.

This should also fix RHBZ: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1348831

Closes-Bug: #1599798

Change-Id: I63871607d748068837c622fd08f2bfef120d27b7

With the fixes for the galera root password:

subject: Add job distribution API features
commit_message:
Add job distribution API features

This patch adds new API functionality related to service nodes, it makes
changes to the service API and also adds a new entry point for nodes,
using microversion 3.2.

With these changes "os-services" listing supports optional argument
`node_detail` that specifies if we want to receive a detailed list of
the nodes for each service.

On service list the response will contain new fields `id`, `num_nodes`,
`num_down_nodes` and `last_heartbeat` indicating the total number of
nodes that are giving service under that host, the number of nodes that
are down, and when the last heartbeat was received from any of those
nodes.

If `node_detail` is set to a true value then we'll return a `nodes`
field which will contain a list of the nodes with the `name`, the
`state` and `heartbeat`.

As for the new "servicenodes" API endpoint, it supports show, index,
detail.

Index and detail support filtering by `host`, `service_id`, `binary`,
`disabled` status, and up/down status (`is_up`) using URL parameters.

No update is possible on service nodes since all fields come from the
configuration or the code itself.

show returns:
    "node": {
        'id': ...,
        'name': ...,
        'state': "up" or "down"
        'updated_at': ...,
        'created_at': ...,
        'report_count': ...,
        'service_id': ...,
        'rpc_version': ...,
        'object_version': ...
    }

index returns:
    "nodes": [
        {
           'id': ...,
           'name': ...,
           'state': "up" or "down"

        { ... },
        ...

detail returns:
    "nodes": [
        {
            'id': ...,

            'updated_at': ...,
            'created_at': ...,
            'report_count': ...,
            'service_id': ...,
            'rpc_version': ...,
            'object_version': ...
        }
        { ... },

    ]

subject: VMware: Reduce volume creation time
commit_message:
VMware: Reduce volume creation time

The volumes (virtual disks) are created on datastores connected to
ESX hosts in vCenter clusters. Currently we create a list of hosts,
filter out hosts in maintenance mode (using one vCenter API call per
host), and then iterate over the filtered list to select a datastore
which is mounted to maximum number of ESX hosts. Ties are broken
based on space utilization.

This approach is not scalable for vCenter installations with large
number of ESX hosts. Also, we always consider the ESX hosts in the
same order and may end up selecting the same set of datastores. This
patch fixes these issues with the datastore selection. It creates a
list of all datastores in vCenter, which is then filtered to remove
unusable datastores and datastores not satisfying the volume requir-
ements. Finally, we select a datastore from the filtered list based
on the number of ESX hosts to which it is mounted and space utiliza-
tion.

image format name, but also a technology, which allows to use
images, stored in files as block devices (like loop devices or
qemu-nbd), but it supports snapshots and has nearly native
performance. qemu-img has limited support of this format - it
can only convert image files, the format is called 'parallels'
in qemu-img.

The main utility to manage such disks is 'ploop'. Here is a man
page - https://static.openvz.org/vz-man/man8/ploop.8.gz.html.
It can create images, make snapshots and create ploop devices,
based on images.

This patch series makes possible all volume operations except for
snapshotting of 'in-use' volumes.

  reliability and speed of connections and to prevent flip-flopping
